div1.p: In a numbered list, Hench names and identifies the figures in the Cornwell yellow fever painting.

div1.head: Suggested Arrangement of Key to Painting, by Philip Showalter Hench, [1941]
div1.p: SUGGESTED ARRANGEMENT OF KEY TO PAINTING (P.S. HENCH)

list.head: SUGGESTED ARRANGEMENT OF KEY TO PAINTING (P.S. HENCH)
list.item:
1. Dr. Carlos Finlay, the Cuban physician who originated and developed the theory
of the transmission of yellow fever by the mosquito but whose work was
ignored for 19 years.

2. Dr. (Major) Walter Reed, President of the United States Army Yellow Fever Board
which proved conclusively the cause of yellow fever.

3. Dr. Jesse W. Lazear, member of the Army Board, inoculating Dr. Carroll with an
infected mosquito. (Dr. Lazear died a month later as a result of self-
experimentation, a martyr to science.)

4. Dr. James Carroll, member of the Army Board, who developed the Board's first
case of experimental yellow fever as a result of the inoculation portrayed.
5. Dr. Aristides Agramonte, Cuban physician and member of the U. S. Army Board.

6. Gen. Leonard Wood, Governor-General of Cuba, who threw the weight of his authority
behind the Board.

7. Major Jefferson R. Kean, Chief Surgeon of the Department of Western Cuba, friend
and advisor of Reed and his colleagues.

item.p:
8. Lieutenant Albert E. Truby, commanding officer of the Columbia Barracks Post
Hospital, Quemados (near Havana) Cuba, where the early experiments were
performed.

(Alternate description: Truby who succeeded Captain A. N. Stark as commanding
officer......etc.) I think the first description is preferable although the
the latter is a little more fair to Stark but I can mention Stark in passing
in my paper.

list.item:
9. Dr. Roger P. Ames, U. S. Army Medical Corps, Yellow fever expert who successfully
cared for the patients with experimental yellow fever.

10. Dr. Robert P. Cooke, contract surgeon U. S. Army Medical Corp who volunteered
to be shut up in a house (Bldg. No. 1) with infected bedding for 20 days to
prove the non-infectiousness of “fomites” (personal belongings).
11. John R. Kissinger, Private, U. S. Army Hospital Corp.

12. John J. Moran, acting steward, Army Hospital Corp. He and Kissinger were the
first two who volunteered to submit to inoculations after the mosquito theory
was accepted by the Yellow Fever Board.

13. Warren G. Jernegan, Private, Hospital Corp who submitted to experiments with
infected clothing and later to inoculation.

14. An American private representative of the eleven additional volunteers:
William H. Dean (case “X-Y”), William Olson, Levi E. Folk, Wallace Forbes,
John H. Andrus, Clyde L. West, James L. Hanberry and Charles G. Sonntag
who accepted inoculations; Edward Weatherwalk, James Hildebrand and Thomas
M. England who were exposed to “fomites.”

15. A Spanish immigrant, representative of the four who volunteered for inoculations:
Antonio Benigno, Nicanor Fernandex, Fincente Presedo and Jose Martinez.
